“m_arm” in my code is the subsystem that the “lowerArm” method belongs to which should be already be defined.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
The problem is that your lowerArm method takes a parameter. Instead of using a method reference ( m_manipulator::lowerArm ) you probably want to use a lambda so you can pass the parameter.

Let’s say your speed is 0.3, you’d do this:

Also, don’t forget to require your subsystem.

Another think I noticed, you might want to use StartEndCommand / Commands.startEnd or .onFalse so the arm stops when you release the button.

EDIT: Fixed a mistake, stopping the arm was missing () -> .

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Kartikr27:

Also, what does xboxController.a() do?

xboxController.a() is from CommandXboxController . Using CommandXboxController instead of XBoxController makes command binding really simple.

Apart from autonomous commands, which are scheduled at the start of the autonomous period, and default commands, which are automatically scheduled whenever their subsystem is not currently in-use, ...

If you use the factories defined on Subsystem instead of the ones in Commands this is done for you automatically.

posts.cooked: Ok I got it to work I made a new stopRotation command and added a Lampfa to it and it seems to be functional.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I think the error is because your Manipulator class doesn’t extend from SubsystemBase ? It should.

Requiring the subsystem tells the scheduler that this command uses the subsystem. As stated in the command-based documentation:

Multiple commands can run concurrently, as long as they do not require the same resources on the robot. Resource management is handled on a per-subsystem basis: commands specify which subsystems they interact with, and the scheduler will ensure that no more more than one command requiring a given subsystem is scheduled at a time. This ensures that, for example, users will not end up with two different pieces of code attempting to set the same motor controller to different output values.

link_counts.title: What Is “Command-Based” Programming? — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
